name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: The agenda calls for debate on the issue with request for an oral response to the Commission on the implementation of regulations on medical devices and medical devices for in vitro diagnostics put forward by Mairead McGuinness, Biljana Borzan, Boleslaw G. Piecha, Gesine Meissner, Kate-ina Kone-nà, Margrete Auken, Piernicola Pedicini, Joelle Mélin, on behalf of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety (O-000085/2018 - B8-0416/2018) (2018/2790 (RSP)).

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: author. – Madam President, this is a really important debate. I think sometimes people might think we legislate and then forget, but actually this debate is about making sure that the legislation on medical devices is implemented in full, and on time. But the reason it has been tabled – and I thank the colleagues who have co-signed with me, we were all involved in this legislation – is that concerns are being raised about the timely implementation.  Let’s reflect on why we had to modernise this law. It was because there were scandals in the medical devices sector, some of a criminal nature, and some identifying problems with how the industry is regulated, the ‘fit-for-purpose’ of notified bodies being one particular issue. So the reason we ask this question is because those concerns on implementation are being raised, but our focus is on patient safety and making sure that there is a supply of devices that are scrutinised fully so that there is no interruption in the medical care and attention that our patients receive.  Can I say that I have a friend going in next week for a knee operation. They are not worried about the gadget, or the knee, because they presume it is going to be safe and effective, and that they will come out skipping, and I hope they will. They are worried just about the operation. I think when patients go into hospital and have a procedure involving a medical device they presume that the medical device is certified and fit for purpose – and we have to give them that guarantee, and that’s the purpose of our question to you this morning.  We are concerned about the Commission’s coordination. There are three different, if you like, DGs of the Commission involved in this, so how is that working, and is it effective? And also, when we were debating this legislation, Brexit wasn’t a reality. It now is, and we have to take account of the implications and consequences of Brexit on the medical device legislation and on the supply of devices that keep our patients safe.  One of the issues that has been raised with us is the expertise available both perhaps within the Commission itself, but also within Member States and within notified bodies, and of the notified bodies that currently operate. I would like the Commission to clarify how many have actually looked for re-designation, as is required under this legislation. I understand it takes 18 months to re-designate a notified body, and if many have not applied at this stage, then we need to know that they will immediately and that they will be certified in time to meet the strict requirements of this legislation.  Lastly, are Member States doing enough? Because they are the ones who are perhaps raising this issue with us as well as the industry, and what do they need to do to make sure that they get this in place in their Member State and on time? Thank you, Commissioner, for taking the question. I look forward to your responses.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, thank you very much for this question as it allows me to update you on the state of play of the implementation of the two regulations on medical devices. I know this is an extremely important issue. We all want the continuous availability of safe and innovative medical devices and, of course, for this we need a smooth transition to the new system. Let me underline, at the very beginning, that so far all relevant legal deadlines established by the regulations have been met. Work is advancing and progressing according to the plans. This was the case for the establishment of the governance structure; the launch of the designation code and procedure for notified bodies; and the delivery of the new plan for the implementation of the new medical devices database (EUDAMED). We had already prepared for the future even before the regulations were adopted. We established effective cooperation with the national competent authorities for medical devices. Together with them, we have elaborated a roadmap of activities to be undertaken during the transitional period. Work is on track to implement the roadmap, again together with the expert groups. We are in continuous dialogue with the notified bodies, industry and all other relevant stakeholders.  As was said in the speech by Ms McGuinness, there are three directorates—general cooperating and sharing responsibilities. We are putting a lot of human resources on this file. But let me assure you, we have a very common understanding of the topic and of the issues between our Commission services. Also, Member States have mobilised their resources to contribute to the implementation process and Member States are fully committed, in the form of the competent authorities for medical devices, to preparing for the future. We are aware that we need enough notified bodies by the end of the transition period. This is a key precondition for the smooth transition. The Commission has set up the entire legal and technical infrastructure to allow for the designation procedure to start as soon as possible. Again, I want to underline that we have been ready from the very first legal date, which was 27 December last year. The number of applications received so far shows that the designation procedure is overall on track.  So far, there have been no delays in assessing the applications of notified bodies. But of course we should not only look at the numbers. The top priority is patient safety. So we should remember that the lack of effective control of the notified bodies under the old system was one of the main reasons to review the medical devices framework. A large share of the responsibility now lies with the notified bodies themselves, as well as with the operators. It is also up to them to prepare and prove their fitness under the revised framework.  A few words on Brexit as it is an extremely important issue. As for all other sectors, this is also a challenge for the medical devices industry. So far, four notified bodies have been established in the UK. In its public notice of January this year, the Commission advised stakeholders to take all necessary measures because, as we all know, a certificate issued by UK notified bodies will no longer be valid as from 29 March next year.  Many other sectors, of course, face the same situation, but, as far as we know, the UK notified bodies and industry associations have been extremely active in preparing for Brexit ahead of time. Four notified bodies have already taken the initiative to adapt to the post—Brexit scenario. Again, we should not rest on our laurels, but for now, we see that they were very proactive and active. So let me conclude by saying that we are on track. There are no deviations from the requirements and deadlines established by Parliament and the Council. So for now, there is no reason to ring the alarm bell. But of course there is still a lot of work ahead of us: first to ensure the transition to the new system but also the availability of devices over the next few years. Therefore, we in the Commission, together we will monitor the implementation process in very close and very constant cooperation with the national competent authorities, the Member States of course, and all other stakeholders.

name: Biljana BORZAN
text: On behalf of club S&D. – Madam Chairman, the purpose of the Regulation on medical devices and in vitro diagnostic devices is to provide European patients with access to safe and efficient devices, and to regain confidence in European production in the wake of the artificial hips and breast implants scandal. The Commission published the initial proposal back in 2012, the trilogues were completed in 2016. Regulations came into force in 2017, with a transition period of three years for medical devices and five years for in vitro diagnostic devices. Esteemed colleagues, we should bear in mind that these new rules have been worked on for as many as six years. Today we are discussing problems in implementing the new rules, because it may happen that by the time the system is starting to apply, the system will not be ready and that the supply of medical devices is suspended. The biggest problem is the adaptation of the named bodies, on which the entire system of placing the device on the market is based. These authorities assess whether medical and in vitro devices meet specifications and regulations before they enter sale and use. The process of ratifying them runs much slower than it should, according to data from May this year, of the 59 existing named bodies, only 30 have initiated the recertification process, and this process takes 18 months.  Unless something changes, it is possible that in May 2020, when the transition period ends, there will be a severe shortage of certification capacities. The situation, of course, is further complicated by Brexit, as a significant number of certifications are made in the UK for the European Union market. But this is not the only problem - the Commission published only a few of the required 18 implementing acts, at the time of writing this oral question. Furthermore, it is not clear whether the EUDAMED system, which is essential for the functioning of the system, will be operational on time. Madam Commissioner, I was pleased to hear your optimistic announcements today and I sincerely hope that all that you have said and will be applied, however understand our concerns as well. I must say that I am not inclined to reopen regulations in order to extend the deadlines and transition period. We should bear in mind that work on these laws started back in 2012 and that Parliament has already agreed to extend the deadlines to trilogues. Our citizens deserve the highest quality service and therefore it is very difficult to explain why this has been going on for so long and I hope that everything that has been said by the Commission today will be put into practice.

name: Gesine MEISSNER
text: Mr President, I would like to like to take a iendled with the ALDE Group. Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. It's almost like a family reunion after the very long and tough negotiations we've been through to get it all on its way. It was a very complicated procedure with very, very many pages – 700 pages, I believe, only in documents from the Council. So it was complicated. The trigger was , as my colleague McGuinness has just said and my other colleague also mentioned – the scandal over breast implants. It was now about patient safety. That is why I think it is a pity that the public gallery is still so empty. It would be nice if a great many people here saw what we are doing well in Europe to ensure patient safety. It was clear from the outset, when we had finished the very difficult negotiations, that the Commission is now in the process of laying the groundwork for the implementation of this regulation. What is it all about? We all know this here, but the medical devices are all sorts of things, from the patch to the scalpel, it is about the operating table, the hospital bed, the artificial hip and the knee joint as well as the pacemaker. And all this is certified in the EU on a decentralised basis through the so-called 'named bodies'. In Germany, what surprises many is even the TÜV, which is actually responsible for road traffic, but also performs these certifications. In 2013 we had 87 notified bodies in the EU, in 2018 only 59. So that was less than more, and seven of them are in the UK. That is why we are very concerned about this. These notified bodies play a very important role. You must certify medical devices. 30 to 45% of medical devices on the market are certified there, and this can be even higher due to specialisation. In the orthopaedic area, for hip or knee joints, it is as much as 70% who are certified there, which is actually a much larger proportion. We need a lot of this, and the declining number of notified bodies and the increasing number of medical devices in the EU are already pushing the existing notified bodies to their capacity limits – I repeat: fewer have become so. There are also new problems. I would like to mention four points. One is that there are real challenges from Brexit, because with Brexit - if it comes, I still hope it won't come - a few jobs will be lost in March 2019 - seven, I've already said it. And then it is to be expected that the number of notified bodies in the other Member States will increase considerably. This is, of course, something that then clearly has capacity limits. In addition, the allowances issued in the United Kingdom would lose their validity – there was a Note from the Commission – and the equipment would then either have to be re-certified in the other 27 Member States, in one of the already overburdened bodies, or they would have to be re-certified, or a post would have to be moved from the UK to the EU, which is certainly hardly feasible by March 2019. The third point is that all medical devices on the market must be certified according to the new regulation by May 2020. In our view, the process of naming the notified bodies, the audit, is not fast enough. Commissioner, you said that the Commission is fully on schedule. We are afraid that it might not be quite the case. After all, manufacturers cannot start certifying their medical devices until the notified bodies are designated in accordance with the new Medical Devices Ordinance. At present, there is not a single notified body that has really been designated. Fourthly, the date of application of the new Medical Devices Ordinance in May 2020 will also result in a higher workload for notified bodies, as more medical devices – scalpel, surgical lamp and so on – will require a certificate than before, and on the other hand, a flood of new certifications is to be expected. It is foreseeable that, with the date of application of the regulation, not all the products currently in use will have a certificate, and thus they would not be usable, and patient care would indeed be at risk. This also puts us at risk of making patient care really difficult after May 2020 and that we will no longer be able to guarantee this. Hip joints with a certificate from the UK, for example, may not be able to be completed in time for the EU 27 Be certified by March 2019, basic surgical equipment such as a scalpel or an operating lamp, which currently do not have a certificate and just need one from May 2020, may not yet be certified and therefore not available due to a lack of capacity. That is why it is - I have heard, Commissioner, what you have said. But do you not really believe – as my colleague Mrs Borzan has just said – that it might be wise to extend the application date by one or two years, so that we are on the safe side and do not risk bottlenecks in patient care?

name: Kateřina KONEČNÁ
text: on the part of the GUE/NGL Group. – Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the implementation of the Regulation on medical devices and in vitro medical devices has many contexts. Unfortunately, both on the part of producers, notified bodies and patients, there are now more questions than answers, and I must admit that many of their concerns are entirely appropriate. It is already clear that the new legislation entails an undesirable reduction in the number of notified bodies. This will mean hampering the entry of new technologies as well as limiting the availability of older resources. E.g. in the Czech Republic, from which I come, we have only two notified bodies left and recently there were five more. Austria no longer has either. The remaining notified bodies are already drowning in work and applications, and it is not enough to handle them, let alone take new clients from countries where there is no longer a notified body, thereby slowly being pushed out of the market by medical device manufacturers from these countries. Of the implemented and delegated acts, only one has been adopted, as far as I know, and even if i accidentally miss one, at this stage it is an absolutely scandalous record. Especially when the first regulation fully enters into force as early as May 2020. Before notification can be made to the NANDO database, it is essential to publish on the website the notification procedure of each Member State. Not a single notification procedure was published there before the summer. Overall, there is a slowdown at European level and the transitional period for the Medical Devices Regulation ceases to seem sufficient. If the situation is not resolved, patients will feel the results. Not to mention that up to 40% of current European certificates are from Britain. However, according to explanatory documents from the European Commission, the EU will lose out entirely with Brexit. Moreover, it is estimated that around half of the authorised representatives in the medical devices sector are based in Britain. Some operators have already announced that they will move their headquarters to the EU, but they will certainly not all do so. For these reasons, the entry of funds into the market will slow down greatly. I therefore have three sub-questions: Firstly, the newly tightened requirements of the Medical Devices Regulation are based on evidence-based principles and evidence based on scientifically correctly interpreted facts. I would therefore like to hear some evidence from the European Commission for its current calm. Do the Representatives of the European Commission consider that the implementation of both regulations is being successfully implemented according to a timetable and therefore there will be no major problems on the market after May 2020? Can the European Commission guarantee that more medical devices will not be transiently removed from the market due to the lack of notified bodies and their capacities? Does the European Commission have any specific studies or in-depth assessments drawn up on this conclusion, and what are the specific findings? What statistics can the European Commission support these conclusions? Are these statistics publicly available? Secondly, the narrow throat for the entry of medical devices into the market is currently the capacity of notified bodies. Is it true, as we often hear here in the kuloárs, that the European Commission prefers to remove all smaller notified bodies in order to reduce their number to around 10 and focus on the few? Can you substantiate future capacity analyses? Before the summer, there were 59 notified bodies under the old legislation, so how much is optimal and sufficient to ensure the functioning of the market, according to the European Commission? Thirdly, harmonised standards and common specifications are one of the cornerstones of the Medical Devices Regulation. As regards standards and their harmonisation to the Medical Devices Regulation, a considerable delay is already planned. Some important standards, such as the biocompatibility assessment, will not be harmonised until May 2024, four years after the first Regulation takes effect. Why did this happen and what is the plan to deal with this delay? I firmly believe, Commissioner, that today you have a unique opportunity to disprove not only my doubts about your inaction or the Commission's inaction, but above all the doubts of the people who are following this point, states that fear that they will not have enough quality and registered medical devices, and patients who are desperately complaining that they do not know how the child of the legislation we have here will work after 2020.
