text: Perfect, I think it was not for Mrs Koneonà but for Mrs Meissner, but here I think things are clear, at least, and unambiguous.

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Madam President, with this oral question on the implementation of the two regulations on medical devices and in vitro diagnostics, we are talking about a potential market of EUR 110 billion. Given the seriousness of the subject, namely the health of Europeans, both on the preventive and curative side, this financial consideration should not be at the forefront. And yet, the PIP breast implant scandal in France has revealed how fundamental and serious the role of notified organizations, those that approve medical devices, is fundamental and serious when they fail. Reform was therefore needed; new regulations have been passed which, 18 months later, do not solve anything, because given the cumbersome European machine, as usual, the consequences are seen, namely that only 30% of the existing notified bodies would have asked for their validation. The fact is that many were British. The deficiencies of these organizations are very worrying, both in terms of their number and the quality of the experts who make them up, but also in terms of the length of the approval processes. The health of all Europeans is at stake, as medical devices range from sparadrap to extracorporeal circulation, from glasses to hip replacements; diagnostic devices are fundamental in daily practice, but also for medium- and long-term prevention. This delay also weighs heavily on many start-ups or large innovative companies, especially in France where self-control is growing very rapidly. Commissioner, you are telling us that everything is taking place, but it is clear that there is a serious delay. This, to say the least, further aggravates the climate of mistrust after the many scandals already old. Should we fear a monopoly of a few certification giants? There is an urgent need, Madam, otherwise the Member States will legitimately take back the hand to protect the health of their citizens, as you will understand.

name: Andreas SCHWAB
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which First of all, I have to say that I arrived late because the emergency medical vehicles are carrying out strike action here in Strasbourg. In a broader sense, this is certainly also linked to the Medical Devices Ordinance. Seriously, however, I believe that what has already been put forward, Commissioner, is really very important, because there are currently around 500 000 medical devices on the market in the European Union. These products must meet the new requirements for patient safety. But they must, in any case, be available in high security for the people who need to get these products directly – even now and in the months to come. That is why the fact that we have this delay in these bodies is simply a major problem for patients in the European Union who are waiting for a product today. Against this background, I would simply like to ask you to do everything possible to increase the number of notified bodies within a framework that allows us to apply the new Medical Devices Regulation as quickly as possible. Mrs McGuinness, who has worked heavily on this dossier, has already pointed this out. There is still a lack of implementing acts that are binding for certification. I believe that you all understand that the companies that manufacture these products can, of course, only adapt to the new rules if they know with an appropriate lead time what requirements they have to meet in detail. It is now clear to me, of course, that it may well also be the case that the Member States share responsibility for this. There is no question about that. But in the end, it does little to help companies if we, as politicians, shift the blame back and forth between the levels of government. Companies need legal certainty and, as far as I know, they also want to implement the requirements of the new Medical Devices Regulation. That is why it is essential to use today's debate to work with the European Commission to find solutions to ensure that companies that produce vital products for patient safety in Europe – but also for patient health – have the opportunity to do so legally in the coming months. I therefore ask all colleagues, and in particular the European Commission.

name: Dobromir SOŚNIERZ
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab This query is a real time machine. As I read these concerned questions: how will it be, whether or not the supply chain of medical supplies will survive our next regulation, I am still reminded of the gatherings of our Communist Party, which I remember from childhood, as communist sages met every year to wonder how to carry out the harvest efficiently this year. And then everything crashed anyway, because there was no string to the snooch. Elsewhere, in other countries, still then on the normal as far as the West, there were sages sitting on the rope to the snooch and the rope to the snooch was always there. And we were not there. And now, too, we have had a wealth of medical articles, no one lacked them, well, the European Union has decided to regulate this, and now we will worry about whether we will work with all this, whether we are not allowed to do everything, because we have three directorates that do not know how they will cooperate with each other, so maybe we will appoint a fourth to coordinate their action, and then a fifth, which will deal with their unification. This is the path that the European Union is taking. So I think our cardboard Altiero Spinelli in the lobby of the Building in Brussels is proud to see in which direction this organisation, which was founded as a tool for free trade and the abolition of regulation, has really become another Communist International.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: – Madam President, I only have to say that my mother and parents also remember very much the communist period that Mr Sośnierz spoke about, when basic medical devices were lacking in Czechoslovakia and I doubt enough that they would not be missing in Poland, so that is a bit of an expression in relation to what my colleague Sośnierz said. However, new regulations on medical devices and in vitro diagnostic medical devices approved in 2016 help ensure that all medical devices are safe and function well. This applies to contact lenses, X-rays, breast implants, artificial joints, etc. To this end, the new rules improve market surveillance and traceability and introduce stricter controls on medical devices. I believe, whether medical devices, cars or other products, there is a need to ensure that we are truly supervised in the interests of our citizens. And from these new rules, we should promise greater transparency, legal certainty for producers and importers, strengthening international competitiveness, as well as new innovations in this strategic sector.  However, already during the three-year transitional period ending in May 2020, it is already showing that the application of the Regulation on medical devices and in vitro diagnostic medical devices is experiencing problems and some elements of the new system are indeed failing to prepare optimally. Much has already been said about this, e.g. the problematic launch of the eudamed database, which should integrate different electronic systems. The proper functioning of this database is very important because it aims to improve access to information for the public, as well as healthcare professionals, in order, for example, to avoid multiple reporting requirements and to also streamline or facilitate the flow of information between economic operators. I would therefore like to ask the Commission, Commissioner, whether the Commission is really convinced that this database will work, whether it has created the necessary conditions for this, and whether this database will serve the purpose I have set out. This is especially for healthcare professionals, but also, of course, for citizens who need to know if, for example, their particular implant will be compatible with the passage of a scanner at the airport.  Another problem worthy of mention is the insufficient number of notified bodies responsible for the certification of medical devices. The Commission should therefore immediately start addressing this situation in order to avoid disruption of the supply of important medical devices to the market. I also expect the Commission to improve coordination between the three Directorates-General concerned in order to receive the necessary administrative support for the new system. (The speaker rejected the question that Dobromir Sośnierz wanted to ask by raising the blue card.)

name: Carlos ZORRINHO
text: – Madam President, the regulation of the use of medical devices and in vitro diagnostic medical devices, based on the definition of design and manufacturing rules, clinical trials, authorisation, marketing and post-marketing surveillance, has proved incapable of preventing the movement in our market of low-quality devices, with serious consequences for users, leaving serious gaps in the legislative system uncovered. It is therefore important to highlight the work done in the European Parliament on this matter, which has given rise to several proposals to improve the functioning, reliability and safety of these devices. It is certain that some Member States have reacted less enthusiastically to the definition of shared regulatory frameworks because, in fact, there is a legislative reserve in health matters. However, the committed work of the European Commission and the European Parliament in dialogue, which is always fundamental with the Member States, has made it possible to take significant steps in cooperation in areas of health quality promotion, which have, as is the case, a clearly cross-border dimension. Strengthening the regulation of in vitro diagnostic medical devices to ensure tests as important as pregnancy tests or blood tests is accurate, needs to be accurate and reliable and is an example where cooperation between Member States is important and needs to be further strengthened. The regulatory framework which entered into force on 25 May 2017, with a transition period of 3 and 5 years respectively, ensures a good quality of these devices and the consequent protection of patients. However, in this period of transposition, difficulties in implementing the system have been identified, in particular in the operationalisation of collaboration between Member States and European bodies. The issue of medical device certification in the UK is also relevant, as, after leaving the European Union, all notified bodies based in the UK will no longer be able to carry out conformity assessments in line with European legislation. Health promotion is legally an intergovernmental competence, but the best interests of citizens require partnerships and concerted responses. That is why, in this context, the questions that have been put to the Commission are of great opportunity and the answers deserve our full attention and all our follow-up.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: – Madam President, the great thing about technical debates is that we are few in number in the debate so we get extra time to respond and I think it’s hugely important. I think it’s also true to say that, if there was a scandal tomorrow on the medical devices industry, this Chamber would be full, so we need to understand that. We’ve lived through a really bad experience and the reputable industry suffered, while the rogues perhaps were not penalised sufficiently. So let me just put that down as a marker.  I want to respond in particular to the answers you’ve given us, Commissioner. I applaud your optimism. I’m quoting my notes here – we’re on track, there’s no delay, there are no alarm bells – and, as Commissioner, you need to show that confidence. But that is not what we are hearing. I’m not raising an alarm bell, but I am raising concerns that I am hearing from regulators, from patient groups and from industry about whether we can implement in full and on time. Like others. I’m not calling for any delays in implementation. I think that would be a really bad signal to our citizens because it took us a long time to get to this place. But I want to make sure that we will actually do that: implement in full and on time. So, I do need you to come back to some of those questions and give me more assurances that we are on track and that there are no delays. Some colleagues raised the issue of the reduction in the numbers of notified bodies. These are the regulators, if you like, that work with industry to make sure products are safe. Let’s remind ourselves of the facts: Before we started on this process of updating our legislation, there were 80 notified bodies across the European Union. When we sent in the auditors, we found that many were not fit for purpose and that there are only 59 of that 80 still operating. That should be an alarm bell. We hope that those 59 are all fit for purpose, that they will apply for re-designation and that it happens on time.  Commissioner, I want to speak about Brexit because I think you need to give us more detail. For example, many would believe that, because we will hopefully have a withdrawal agreement, there will be a transition or implementation period and that nothing will change around the medical devices sector until the end of that period. But, as I heard from you, that is not the case, so please clarify when the change comes. Is it at the end of March or at the end of the transition? The second question – and perhaps the more pertinent one – is that the UK is a major player in this industry and also has many notified bodies. More detail please on what those notified bodies, that are located in the United Kingdom, are doing so that they can continue their work because I fear, if they left the stage, then we do have an alarm bell and we will be ringing it.

name: Tiemo WÖLKEN
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her The two new regulations, as has been said here several times in the chamber, are intended to ensure that patients in the European Union have access to safe and effective medical devices. As a house, we are definitely sticking to this goal. The scandals of faulty breast implants or hip joints have shown just how important this is. Only we at European level can set common standards, because medical devices are also traded in the European internal market and cross borders. This is also shown very clearly by the example of Brexit, our priority has always been patient safety in all the legislation, which has unfortunately dragged on for a very long time. The two texts take account of this patient safety. They increase the requirements for medical product manufacturers or monitoring associations such as TÜV or Dekra. In the new regulation, we in parliament have ensured, among other things, that manufacturers of medical products will need adequate insurance in future, so that patients are at least financially protected in the event of damage. However, it is not acceptable that, just before the date of implementation, we have to state that important implementing acts are not yet on the table and that important measures that lead to improving patient safety have not actually been implemented. I do not think that the necessary elements of the system should suddenly be prepared just before the regulation enters into force. In particular, and my fellow Members have already rightly stated this, there is the problem of the timely designation of notified bodies, the notified bodies. That is the core element of the regulation. For me, therefore, it must be made quite clear here that this must definitely be implemented. It cannot be the solution to postpone the date of application of this regulation, which we have been going through for so long, including with the Council. It is important to ensure that the application period begins in May 2020. The Commissioner's response to the notified bodies is not enough for me. I do not see that patient safety is really guaranteed in the European Union, and I would therefore like to see a clarification once again and, like Mrs McGuinness, I would like to go back here with a request to make it clear what Brexit means.

name: Soledad CABEZÓN RUIZ
text: – Madam President, it has already been said here; we remember all the scandals with breast prostheses: hundreds of thousands of people affected; We all remember the scandal with the hip prostheses of the company Traiber: since 2014, in the case of Spain, seventy-four people reoperated, and one of them even cost her life. So, we're not talking about a ballad. It's about patient safety. I can understand that the Commission is facing a new challenge which needs qualified personnel, that we are also faced with the Brexit situation and that, indeed, much of these assessments and these experts came from the United Kingdom.  I therefore call for the necessary measures to be taken to implement it. We're talking—as I say—about patient safety. A regulation, moreover, which is a part of security as an objective but perhaps suffers from the necessary lack of ambition. Efficiency would even need to be considered, because ideally we had a centralised authorisation system in the European Union for this type of device, which ensured safety and efficiency.  Today we talk about security as a first step; we'll have to keep talking about efficiency. But I ask the Commission to put the batteries on because it is indeed one of the great challenges facing national health systems and patients today. Therefore, I encourage you not to delay the introduction and implementation of this type of regulation any longer. And finally, a specific issue. Is it quite a bureaucratic problem or is there also pressure from some stakeholder or some sector that you believe is not yet ready for this to be implemented? I would like to know, because I really believe that it is an opportunity even for the competitiveness of the European Union in terms of quality. I am aware that there is some resistance and I would like to know if it is only a bureaucratic problem.  (She agreed to answer a question posed in accordance with the 'blue card' procedure (Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)).

name: Gesine MEISSNER
text: Question about the procedure of the "blue card". Yes, I am the only one who has said so far: if necessary, we must take an extension of the deadlines. That is not at all what I would like, of course. Of course, it would be best if we had implemented it by 2020. But, Mrs Soledad, do you not also think that it might be smarter to think about extending the deadline if we really saw that it does not work to be ready in time? We are all afraid that the Commission may not be able to deal with the design of the notified bodies in good time. That is my concern.

name: Soledad CABEZÓN RUIZ
text: "blue card" response. – I am aware that we all want this implementation to be done as soon as possible, but I wanted to ask the Commission whether it is only, indeed, a bureaucratic problem, of means, of staff, of qualification. If so, we have to study it, although that doesn't mean we don't have to ask you to please speed up and commit to a security issue like this. But I have also wanted to make you see or ask if there may indeed be some kind of insecurity or doubt that this cannot go, say, as fast as possible because there is some sector that you feel is not prepared for it. I believe that, if that is the case, we must avoid it, because the Regulation is more necessary than ever. I believe that the sector is prepared and Europe needs me to become part of this Regulation.

name: Michèle RIVASI
text: Madam President, for me this subject is very important and - I anticipate - I think there is going to be a health scandal on these medical devices. What for? Because when we worked on this regulation, we wanted to make a centralized body, like what exists in the United States, but the Liberals and the Conservatives did not want to say, "We are going to trust the certification bodies." So I looked at the certification bodies and I put out a reference number where there is an excerpt from a summary report by the DG "Health and Food Safety". What does this internal report say? That joint evaluations — you know that there were 78 certification bodies and now it is thought that there will be only 53 — show that there are recurring and persistent problems with the way notified organizations work and their ability to meet the designation requirements of the guidelines: lack of independence, impartiality of staff of notified agencies , insufficient evidence to justify staff qualification and assignment to specific compliance assessment functions and to achieve far from optimal compliance assessments for medical devices.  So it is your internal report that shows that certification bodies are private bodies and from the moment they are private, they are judges and parties, and at the same time they do not have the qualification at the expert level. You're the one who's saying it! So when we're going to have implants — you see, things that are inside the body — and if there are no good epidemiologists, if there are no qualified staff to evaluate clinical studies, to analyze the impact of metals at the level, for example, of bones and blood, which has happened for hip replacements, then we are going to face health scandals.  To cite just one example: during the PIP prosthetics scandal in France, the German body T-V went to check them and they did not see that the building blocks of these prostheses were not compliant. As for ASR hip replacements, they were marketed by Johnson and Johnson from 2003 to 2010. 93,000 people worldwide, including more than 100 in France, have had these prostheses. It was not the notification agencies that reported the problem: it was only because the United States banned them, and then Australia, that France ended up banning them as well. You can see that we are not up to the challenge. On pacemakers and the rest there will also be scandals because our system does not work as it is. We were told: no centralized body, because we have to encourage innovation. But innovation at the expense of patient safety is not acceptable. We must therefore consider a centralised body under the aegis of the European Commission which specifically analyses the effectiveness and safety of the devices.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, today's debate shows that we still have a lot to do in this area and we need to start from the safety and security of patients, as has been very much stressed here. New manufacturers have entered the market, we have companies that make prosthetics, cabinets that make implants but the results, Commissioner, in many states are negative. There are patients who remain disabled for life after surgery with certain devices. And I think that here we need to think not necessarily to do the work quickly, but to do it well. And I'm glad there were other such voices here. I would like to ask you if you think that now, when we are in the phase of implementing this regulation within a certain time frame, we have updated studies of the effect that implants have, the effect that prostheses have, because that is how you could help the Member States. Health is under subsidiarity, but we can here have, in Europe, some elements to help the Member States in the implementation of the regulation.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Madam President, technology is of course also being used in health matters, and this is quite right, because that is how we can make progress. So we have too many medical devices. We have in vitro diagnostic medical devices, other products, which, of course, generate a turnover together with health interventions of one hundred and ten billion euros. It's too much money, as they say. So we have prosthetics, the rays, the blood tests, the pregnancy tests, the pacemakers. It is understood that there must be specifications and these specifications must be approved by certified bodies, which must have certain specifications as well. Have the necessary technology. There should be no conflict of interest. To have the expertise and, I would say, to have a public character. That is why I believe that to a large extent it must be a public nature of the bodies that certify and, if we have private bodies, there should be a safeguard for the conflict of interest to make sure that the job is done properly.

name: Julie WARD
text: – Madam President, I would like to use this opportunity to pay tribute to the important work of Dame Glenis Willmott, who until a year ago was the leader of the British Labour delegation here in the European Parliament.  Glenys knew her subject because she had worked in the health sector as a trade union representative. Her work on the safety of medical devices was promoted by the scandal of leaking breast-implants; an issue that seriously threatened the health of women, and I am proud that we have real experts in our political group working for the benefit of all Europeans, and I have to say that my colleague Mrs McGuinness is correct: Brexit threatens the future health of people in the UK and Ireland. It also threatens research: ground-breaking research is what makes medicines and health innovations possible – and outside of the EU, the UK is taking a retrograde step in terms of its position on the world stage.

name: Julie WARD
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I would to thank the honourable Members for all their remarks. First, many of you said that I am optimistic and calm. I would rather put it in other words: Iʼm realistic and confident. It does not mean that we are not monitoring proactively everything that is going on, that we are not watching the process. But for now, we are in the timeline, we are on track and in the timeline, and this is the most important thing. I would also like to underline that with this regulation, European citizens – EU citizens – will receive the most reliable, the most innovative and the safest healthcare in the world. This is the aim of this legislation. This is why we doing this, for the safety of our citizens. Let me refer to a few points that you raised. First, on the number of notified bodies. For now, we have 60 of them and 34 applications, so more than half have been received by the Commission. There have been no delays so far in the assessment of notified bodies that have been submitted to us. According to our data, the first notified bodies might be available even before the end of this year, so a few months in advance of the timeline. As for the transition period for this directive (not Brexit), in order to smooth the transition, the two regulations foresee a specific exemption mechanism – of course under certain conditions, namely the extension of the validity of the old certificates and the exemption of certain devices from the new, more strict clinical investigation requirements. Those exemptions and those applications may end even in May 2024, so we have some exemptions in the regulation. Brexit: an extremely important topic. You mentioned the transition period, but of course the transition period for Brexit is much more general and much broader than only the medical devices industry. It applies to all of the industrial sectors, and of course if any transition period for general transition periods is agreed, then it will also apply for this industrial sector. But according to our information, the four UK notified bodies have already taken initiatives, as I said before, to adapt to the post-Brexit scenario. The largest UK-notified body, BSI, is in the process of new designation in the Netherlands; this is expected to be completed in November. Another – SGS – already has local offices in Finland and Belgium, which could inherit certificates transferred from the UK. The two other notified bodies – UL and LRQA – have approached the same national authorities for a possible application, according to our information. So this is what the UK-notified bodies are doing. But of course, if any additional transitional period is agreed, then perhaps we might have some more time beyond 29 March. There was also a question on the database. Work has so far been advancing, and again – not optimistically but realistically – we are in the timeframe. According to our plans, a first release of the plan for the implementation of the functional specification was accomplished by the legal deadline foreseen of 26 May this year, and the draft functional specification I expect to be ready by the end of this month (in one week). Again, here also we are in the timeframe. But I want to assure you, as I said a few sentences ago, that we are proactively monitoring the situation. I know that in some Member States there are some problems with the notified bodies, and I also practically discuss it with ministers and the governments of those countries, but for now we are on track and we are doing our best to face this challenge, but also to implement the new legal framework in a successful and timely manner.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: The debate is closed.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: The agenda calls for the brief presentation of Ismail Ertug's report on the establishment of the infrastructure needed for the use of alternative fuels in the European Union: the time for action (2018/2023 (INI)) (A8-0279/2018).

name: Ismail ERTUG
text: Rapporteur. Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the commissioner for her excellent work and for the work she has done.  Together we now have a major task ahead of us as the European Union, which is to build infrastructures for alternative fuels. These infrastructures, which are a key element for the mobility revolution that we all want to tackle, together with the legislation on CO2 and European battery cell production. The citizens of Europe must be able to be sure that they can reach their destination safely, even with battery-powered vehicles or hydrogen-powered vehicles – just as they are today with their petrol or diesel cars.  The European Commission originally wanted to build 800,000 charging stations across Europe by 2025. Today we have just over 100 000, and hydrogen filling stations are not even included in Directive 2014/94, the Alternative Fuel Infrastructure Directive. I would like to thank my shadow rapporteurs for their constructive cooperation. I believe that we have prepared a very promising report. In it, we call for cofinancing of this infrastructure with about 10% public participation and the remaining sum to be raised by the industries involved. We are also asking for EUR 2.5 billion to build this infrastructure, and we believe that this must be made available. That is more than three times as much as the Commission has cautiously recommended with its 800 million. We also call for each Member State to fulfil its own infrastructure objectives. At this point, I would like to mention once again – and there is also a criticism of the European Commission: the national framework plans, which were just five or four years ago being raised by industry and various Member States that desperately wanted to destroy it, have proved to be a weak instrument. They have done almost nothing. We have always said – even as a Parliament with a large majority here – that we are in favour of technology neutrality. If we invoke technological neutrality, then we must also – in my opinion – promote the expansion not only of electric charging stations, but also of hydrogen charging stations and filling stations. This is essential.  It is also essential that we also improve so-called sectoral coupling. In other words, the interplay of the energy sector with the mobility sector. Member States are also required to make more climate-friendly fuels, such as electricity or green hydrogen, tax-friendly than diesel or petrol. We also call for greater decarbonisation of the shipping sector. I think we have seen this happen to all of us before, that the citizens immediately ask us, in relation to this debate on driving bans and the like, why we are so focused on the car, when these very big ships are travelling in the world rather dirty. I must agree with those who are talking to us about this and call on the Commission to finally introduce a system here too that, for example.B anchoring ships, are supplied with electricity from land and that dirty diesel engines are not allowed to enter ports.  That is shortly the paper that we have prepared here in the European Parliament. Once again, I would like to thank all my colleagues who have contributed to this.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, Mr Erug, it is a debate that we are not only having on the occasion of this report, we have been discussing it for a very long time, we need decarbonisation. I believe, Commissioner, that there is also a need for a system of incentives for car manufacturers to be able to make innovation, investments in modern technology. I also believe that emphasis needs to be placed on urban mobility and mobility at airports. The first ones that could decarbonize, go on electric cars alternative to the ones we now have on fuel - local authorities. I very much believe, however, that there is a need - and it has been pointed out here - for a larger budget to create infrastructure, because there are states that have no infrastructure for electricity at all, and then for nothing would anyone want to buy a car or the industry produces such cars. I believe that there must be a Commission policy that is applied afterwards and in the Member States.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Madam President, the infrastructure of alternative fuels is really something very serious. I'll give you an example. There is interest in Greece in buying electric cars. Only today electric cars have an autonomous function up to two hundred kilometers and from there one has to find a place to recharge. And if anyone wanted to leave Athens to Thessaloniki, which is about five hundred kilometers, they have to be sure that they will find somewhere to recharge the car battery, otherwise they will stay and stop. You understand, then, that it is quite right to move on to new technologies, but that requires infrastructure. And in order to become infrastructure, investment must be made. And in order to move on to this process, of course, we need funds which must be drawn up at European Union and Member State level. So we have and we have to move on to new technologies, but that takes patience and we cannot throw all conventional cars in the bin in one go. These are problems that need to be addressed.

name: Gesine MEISSNER
text: Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has done I would like to thank Ismail Ertug very much. We have both worked together when it came to legislation on alternative fuels, and even then Parliament was actually much more ambitious – unfortunately – than the Member States, because the Member States have once again negotiated the implementation phase backwards. We really have a hen-egg problem now. For example, there are already ships that use LNG, but there are not enough ports where you can refuel, so to speak. Various vehicles with alternative drives are already in production, but it is not yet certain whether the infrastructure is there for this. And as long as this is not guaranteed, they will not be bought and used. As Ismail Ertrug has pointed out, we want technology neutrality not just e-mobility, but everything. But in order to implement this properly, in order to get the products on the road, on the railways, on the water afterwards, we really need the infrastructure. That is why it is high time. Unfortunately, it is not possible to speed things up during an implementation phase and say: 'We want other deadlines'. That is what we in the Committee on Transport and Transport would have preferred to do, but unfortunately that is not possible. That is why I would like to appeal to the Member States to build the infrastructure as quickly as possible.

name: Gesine MEISSNER
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, firstly, I want to thank you for this report as it is really important in our efforts to establish in Europe low carbon emissions and an energy-efficient green economy and the Commission fully agrees with both the rapporteur and also the Committee on Transport that decisive and swift action is needed on the deployment of the infrastructure for alternative fuels. We welcome the constant support of this House to make this happen. Our action plan adopted in November last year gives a very clear picture of the investment gap as well as of the need for improved coordination both in the public and private sector in this respect. As regards the report’s call for quickly reviewing the directive, for now, the Commission is preparing to launch a formal ex-post evaluation of the directive. In that context, we will also consider the need for legislative follow-up action on issues that are important for alternative fuels infrastructure but which are not regulated under this directive. For example, recharging related services – such as location information, payment, vehicles to greet services – are very important to make recharging alternative fuel as easy as with conventional ones. We think that with reviewing the directive before the evaluation is concluded would be premature now. The directive itself foresees a possible review of the legislative framework in place by the end of 2020 at the earliest. Moreover, the directive has just been transposed into the legal systems and national laws in the Member States. The Commission has been – and we are still – closely following the implementation, and we are taking the necessary legal action through enforcement, through infringements, of course. In parallel to this evaluation process, we will continue supporting and facilitating the process of better collaboration and good practice sharing. While we see, of course, that national policy frameworks have their shortcomings, we also see on the other hand that they have acted in many Member States as a catalyst of development in this field. The Commission also agrees with the report’s conclusion – and some of you also mentioned that – that we need to mobilise additional finance, particularly from the private sector. We had a very good response to our current approach to blending grants with loans under the Connecting Europe Facility (CEF), especially for projects in the area of alternative fuels. The Commission is therefore in the process of establishing a blending facility under the Connecting Europe facility. It will make EU financing accessible on a flexible first-come, first-assessed basis. When the project reaches sufficient maturity, the assessment of the project will always take place according, of course, to the legal basis of their respective funding programmes, whether it is the Connecting Europe Facility, FCO, Future Invest EU. It is in our best interests to have a full pipeline of mature projects with a real market impact but of course without market distortions.  Finally, the Commission very much welcomes the positive reception of the European battery alliance that we proposed and the joint undertaking on fuel cells and hydrogen. It is clear that we need a level playing field where all alternative fuels can compete to the best effect that we want to achieve. Thank you very much.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place today at noon. Written statements (Article 162)

name: Andor DELI
text: Writing. – Transport is the only major economic sector in the Union where greenhouse gas emissions (GHG) have increased since 1990. This is largely due to the use of conventional fuels. In addition to conventional fuels, we should use more alternative fuels. To this end, it is necessary to build the infrastructure of these fuels and to maintain existing stations. It is primarily the responsibility of the Member States to build adequate infrastructure for alternative fuels, but unfortunately it can be observed that member states vary in ambition as well as in terms of funding. The European Commission must play a greater role in ensuring that all Member States develop in this area.  Member States need to be helped individually, which is why I think it is important for those responsible to come up with technology-neutral solutions and to be flexible about the situation of each state, to be open in order to achieve the objectives as much as possible everywhere. In addition, I think it is important to point out that particular attention should be paid to the Member States that joined in 2004 and later, especially in the East. These countries should not be allowed to lag behind the more developed states that have joined in the past.

name: Rolandas PAKSAS
text: Writing. – There is a lot and often talk in Europe about the need to move towards clean energy. However, it is very important to assess the situation in each country: how much investment should be made in the deployment of the new infrastructure, how much progress has been made in the states in this area. The most important thing is that the implementation of the objectives is not too fast or ill-planned to become an unbearable burden on the state. The Union needs to carefully calculate the amounts of support granted to states, taking into account possible unplanned expenditure. It is not enough to promote the purchase and use of electric vehicles alone. After all, equipment for use must also be taken care of. There is also a sufficient number of this equipment on the roads.  I fully support clean mobility and support the use of alternative biofuels. I support scientific and technological progress. It is therefore essential that investment technologies to achieve clean mobility objectives in all EU countries and to increase technology capacity in order to ensure the quality of consumption is constantly encouraged.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: The agenda calls for the brief presentation of Joachim Schuster's report "Mastering Globalization: Trade Aspects" (2018/2005 (INI)) (A8-0319/2018).

name: Joachim SCHUSTER
text: Rapporteur. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which The global economy has been in disarray. The US is dismantling the order that it itself built after World War II, and if it goes after Trump, the law of the strongest should apply in the future. But Trump is not the only factor in the global economy. We are dealing with several fundamental trends. In the past, firstly, the quality of international economic relations has changed: trade in finished products is no longer dominated, but trade in international value chains. Secondly, globalisation not only leads to greater prosperity overall, but also to losers – regionally, sectorally, and also in relation to individual groups of people. Incidentally, this fact is also one, but by no means the sole cause, of the rising nationalism in, for example, in the United States and the EU. Thirdly, the weights of the individual states are shifting considerably. China is the rising force, and there is no doubt that the global economic center is shifting to East Asia. The relative weight of the US and the EU is decreasing in a mirror image. It is becoming clear that China will replace the US as the dominant economic power in the coming decades. This will go hand in hand with China's attempt to reorganise the basic rules of the world economy according to its interests. Fourthly, the existing multilateral world order is under increasing pressure. The WTO is currently unable to structure world trade. There are also other policy changes. At the same time, other global problems are becoming acute. I will mention climate change, the increase in military conflicts, the increase in migration worldwide, poverty and malnutrition of several hundred million people. That is why economic globalisation in the 21st century must also contribute to achieving the UN's Sustainable Development Goals. It is not enough for the EU to develop a strategy in response to Trump that merely seeks to secure rules-based world trade through bilateral agreements with as many partners as possible. We need a more complex response, in which advocating for the rules-based world economy is an important but only one element. Internally, the first thing to do is to strengthen our own internal market and to counter nationalism. The EU must support European regions and people in global structural change. Key words here are comprehensive reform and strengthening of the Globalisation Adjustment Fund, the use of structural policies to strengthen competitiveness and innovation – with particular attention to small and medium-sized enterprises – support for employment through training, the development of trade defence instruments or even targeted investment screening. Externally, we should focus more efforts on finding or helping to develop new powerful allies. I am referring in particular to economic relations with the African countries, but also with the successor states of the former Soviet Union, including Russia. However, our foreign economic policy must also be serious about the postulate of value-based trade. Trade not only serves to increase economic profit opportunities, but also to help improve working conditions. Here, ratification and compliance with the ILO core labour standard are minimum conditions and must help to achieve the sustainable development goals. Social, labour and environmental dumping must not be a means of achieving international competitive advantages. This not only undermines popular acceptance, but simply destroys our natural livelihoods. That is why we Social Democrats keep insisting that trade agreements contain comprehensive and enforceable sustainability chapters. The refusal of the Commission and some Member States to take this issue seriously is, in my view, an expression of inability to look for the future. A modern global economic strategy must be more than adherence to rules-based world trade. We also need answers to the power-political challenges and we must always see world trade as an instrument for enforcing sustainability.

name: Laima Liucija ANDRIKIENĖ
text: – Madam President, first I want to congratulate our rapporteur for his work on this report. I think the Committee on International Trade (INTA) has adopted a very well—balanced report on the trade aspects of harnessing globalisation. However, there is an amendment tabled for the plenary, which has been rejected in the INTA Committee, on a sanctions-based enforcement mechanism in the EU’s TSD chapters. This would oblige the EU to find ways to determine how a breach of social or environmental standards can be transformed into economic compensation and this narrows down the scope of the TSD chapter. We cannot agree with this. Such an approach does not fit with the EU’s model. The Commission already has a 15—point plan to make the EU TSD chapters more effective. Colleagues, I call on you to vote against this amendment, as its adoption would mean a significant setback for our trade policy and send the wrong message to our trading partners and the Commission.

name: Julie WARD
text: – Madam President, this report is very important as our trade policy has implications across many other areas. As a socialist, I am proud to be part of a parliament that takes the initiative to reflect on the need to fight inequalities created by globalisation. European companies are responsible for many inequalities and human rights violations in the world and it’s our responsibility to put in place legal safeguards to prevent them from harming populations in third countries. Regarding foreign policy, trade is a powerful tool for the EU to promote international law, particularly human rights. But to do that we must step up and improve the way we engage with partners in the trade area. Free trade agreements should be designed so they don’t undermine national and international laws and should include strong mechanisms, including the sustainable development chapters, to be respected by all parties. Commissioner, regarding the impact of globalisation and robotisation on the future of work, I wish to remind you of our conversation about occupational literacy at the recent EIF debate.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Madam President, the European Union is rooted in the old EEC and the basic principle of the EEC was the principle of Community preference. A principle which supported the products of the Member States of the EEC at the time, and indeed this had a strong dimension in the common agricultural policy. It was a system of mild protectionism in order to counter international competition. In the process, of course, the EEC and the United States have succeeded in opening up the markets. But opening up of markets also means, of course, free trade within the European Union, from countries that produce cheaply, from European companies that have invested in the developing world, because there the pay was cheap. As a result, the European Union's own economy is being dismantled. Now we have suddenly remembered the mild protectionism, which we call the protection of citizens. From the moment I am here I am talking about restoring the principle of Community preference. I hope it's not too late.

name: Bill ETHERIDGE
text: – Madam President, trade and the markets are organic, they are almost a living organism, they’re made up of individuality and people’s wants and desires. If you try to stand in the way of the flow of trade in the free market and of enterprise, all you’re doing is being a modern—day King Canute and you will get washed away. The important thing is to bring down trade barriers, to bring down protection, to bring down tariffs, to trade freely with the world, to make our people wealthier and better off. If you allow this to happen, what happens then is that, when people are wealthier and better off, they start to make their choices. They will then choose if they wish to buy from morally and ethically correct companies because they will then have decisions that they can take. It’s about people. Employing and putting and imposing rules on – they’re all about politics and good intentions. All it does is make trade and the economy in European countries weaker and the citizens poorer.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, globalisation must be seen how we make the most of it. From my point of view - I have been talking here here about the internal market for four years, you know that I am part of the IMCO Committee - and I have often raised this issue: how do we make the most of globalisation? How do we have free trade, as the colleague said, but it has to be ethical and fair. We need to have consumer protection, we cannot let products enter the internal market without product safety. Or here I think we have a lot of things to deal with in terms of trade agreements, product standards, the conditions that we put into product quality and the extension of trade agreements with other states. It is a time of global crisis, we recognise this, but we need to get away from these things: ethical and fair trade, consumer protection, consumer safety and, why not, think about how we make SMEs in the European Union's internal market resist and develop - because we know well that it is a problem now in terms of sME capitalisation.

name: Jude KIRTON-DARLING
text: – Madam President, I would like to say to the Commissioner that the EU talks the talk about harnessing globalisation but talking isn’t enough. While globalisation has lifted many out of extreme poverty globally, it has increased the inequalities in our societies to breaking point. That’s largely because trade policies focused almost exclusively on trade liberalisation and market opening without any real consideration of the negative impacts on some sectors, regions and parts of society. Just as the emerging EU single market needed a social dimension, so too does our trade policy. Both need strengthening. Our trade and sustainable development chapters need teeth as well as incentives for good behaviour. The Commission’s opposition to trade sanctions for labour and environmental roles means serial violators fear no economic cost of human rights abuses. Harnessing globalisation means setting clear rules, rules for business, and ensuring rights for people.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, international trade not only plays a decisive role in economic development and cooperation between countries, but also has a fundamental influence on peace, sustainable growth, employment, poverty eradication and human rights. However, the benefits of globalisation are not evenly distributed between regions and within society. The global multilateral economic order, with the WTO at its heart, is struggling to integrate the profound changes of recent decades, from the new role of China and the United States to the automation and digitalisation of the economy. Fairer conditions must be ensured for SMEs. I agree with the call for an EU trade strategy for SMEs, in order to integrate them into international value chains and overcome specific barriers to trade, such as non-tariff barriers. Effective trade defence and consumer protection instruments are needed. I therefore call on the Commission to continue to develop safe methods to take full account of these dimensions, including with regard to the social and environmental standards applicable in exporting countries.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I want to thank the rapporteur, the Committee on International Trade (INTA) and the whole Parliament for this report, as it’s extremely important. As you have pointed out in the report, globalisation is profoundly changing the world economic order, and we have a duty to harness this phenomenon. This is necessary to ensure that globalisation is used as a force for progress in favour of more sustainable and more inclusive growth. This report is also timely and the vote today is timely. The rules and values-based international trading order is facing the deepest crisis since the end of the Second World War. The rules at the core of the international trading system are increasingly being challenged by some – even major – global players. The Commission totally subscribes to the report’s recommendation that we should avoid resorting to protectionism. Protectionism is an easy answer to common fears, as we all know, but it has always come with often catastrophic consequences in the longer term. The Commission also concurs that itʼs vitally important to preserve the multilateral world economic order, to ensure that it remains rule- and value-based. This is why the EU is a leading advocate of the rule- and value-based international trade system – of course, with the World Trade Organization at its centre – while acknowledging that these rules need to be updated. This report also rightly underlines the importance of promoting sustainable development with our trade policy. This is what the EU does with the chapters on trade and sustainable development in our free trade agreements. These chapters are designed to make sure that trade policy goes hand in hand with high labour and environmental standards and with the promotion of corporate social responsibility (CSR) and other trade and investment practices supporting sustainable development. As announced by my colleague, Commissioner Malmström, in her 15—point action plan to make the EU trade and sustainable development chapter more effective, the Commission’s aims are to ensure that countries comply with the commitments to more assertive enforcement; to facilitate the monitoring role of social partners and civil society; and to make EU resources available to support implementation of the sustainable development chapters in trade agreements. Let me now turn your attention to two countries that I think are extremely important in this respect: Cambodia and Myanmar. Both of those countries benefit from the Everything But Arms arrangement, which guarantees completely tariff—free access to the European market for all export goods except for weapons and ammunition. However, this access is not without conditions, and in the case of Myanmar, the Commission will soon send a high-level EU mission there to assess the situation on the ground. This mission has to be seen within the framework of the possible withdrawal of those preferences. With Cambodia, we are even a step further in the process. Without clear and evident improvements on the ground, the process will result in the suspension of the trade preferences that Cambodia currently enjoys. The Commission also has other concrete trade measures in place that support sustainable development: the Conflict Minerals Regulation; the Fair and Ethical Trade Award; and EU support for responsible business conduct. EU values are, furthermore, promoted through an updated regulation preventing the export of goods that could be used for capital punishment or torture. So let me conclude by saying that the Commission will, of course, take your valuable recommendations into consideration for our future work on trade policy. In line with your request, the Commission will continue to work to make sure that globalisation helps bring more sustainable, more inclusive growth while at the same time defending the rules and values that the international trading order is based on.

name: Agnes JONGERIUS
text: Written. – Globalisation brings new challenges, but also uncertainties. As far as I am concerned, the European Union must come up with an honest answer, in which social labour standards and environmental standards prevail. We must not lose sight of our values, even when production takes place on the other side of the world.  Europe can, and must, take the lead in promoting and promoting social, labour and human rights. Any new or renewed trade treaty must explicitly include these issues, such as the ILO Treaties and the Paris Agreement. However, it is not only about recording standards, but also about complying with them. The civil society of our trading partners must play an important role in this. Penalties must therefore be imposed on breaches of standards.  Globalisation affects us in an unequal way. We must minimise the loss caused by globalisation. The answer to globalisation can also be simple: no, we will not turn a blind eye if, for example, that puts the lives of millions of workers at risk.

name: Bogusław LIBERADZKI
text: The next item is the brief presentation of the report by Cătălin Sorin Ivan on the protection of the EU's financial interests – Recovery of funds and assets from third countries in cases of fraud 2018/2006(INI) (A8-0298/2018).

name: Cătălin Sorin IVAN
text: Rapporteur. – Mr President, Commissioner, this report must be seen from three perspectives. Firstly, a social perspective - almost 70% of the citizens of the European Union say that their countries are severely and very badly affected by corruption. Then, from an economic perspective - because between 700 and 1 800 billion euros is the value of money laundered worldwide. Unfortunately, we do not have a figure at European Union level. Between 2 and 5 % of the gross global product is money laundered. And three, from a political perspective - because at European level, at the moment, there is no political will in any Member State of the European Union that the issue of recovery of illegal assets taken out of the European Union is solved. There is no such political will and it is very easy to understand, because in many Member States many politicians have built their political careers through money from illegal businesses, have reached very important positions in those states and have laundered this provenance of money, winning some choices through the democratic mechanisms that we know, and now they control governments, they control parliaments , pass laws that protect corruption in Member States of the European Union. In this context, the question that the nearly 70% of the citizens of the European Union ask us is: is the European Union fighting corruption? Does the European Union have real, effective, concrete policies to stop this phenomenon of corruption? In this report we are coming to complement steps already taken by the European Union and we are proposing some concrete things. Firstly, we propose that at European Union level there should be a risk map of the laws of the Member States of those 'escapes' from national laws - I say "escapes" in quotation marks for them are often well thought out - whereby money is taken out of the European Union in different countries. Secondly, we are asking for an interconnected database or databases with data collected in a standardised manner, real communication between the Member States of the European Union, so that we know in real time information from all these Member States. We have states in the European Union where there are two or three offices for the recovery of money and illegal property, but these offices do not communicate with each other. If they do not communicate with each other at Member State level, how will they communicate at European level? Thirdly, we call on the European Union to speak with one voice with third countries when it comes to recovering these illegal assets. At the moment, the European Union has only four partnerships signed: with Japan, with the United States, with Norway and with Liechtenstein. It's very, very little. We also demand that this European mechanism that we want to build, which we need to build to speak with one voice, has the European Public Prosecutor's Office at its heart. And last but not least - it is not foreseen in the report, but I think it is an important step in the future, because if we want to stop corruption, then we have to get this money back - it is that at European level we take the decision once and for all that corruption should never be prescribed in 10 and 15 and 20 years from now. , if we learn of corruption, let us recover the assets of these acts of corruption, whether we have found them in the second or third generation. Those who steal public money know that they will never escape the watchful eye of the law.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, it is a pity that at such a debate we are so few, because we are going back to our states and we are claiming that there is a lot of fraud, a lot of evasion. They are now trying - I say shyly - from the level of the European Union to find a solution. The solution is very clear. On the one hand, there should be a very clear law in all national parliaments, in all states, not to fill prisons, not to build new prisons from the budget, but to recover money from fraud-seekers. For this we need to have a very well-developed information system between states, because unfortunately this information system does not work, even though we have a lot of agencies, institutions and Europol and others. On the other hand, we do not have a very clear european Union framework in relation to third countries, and then there is a haven of money in these third countries. I believe that this is where the European Commission must act with very serious proposals for regulations at European level in order to have mechanisms through which to supervise, to photograph the whole internal market in terms of tax evasion, economic crime, not to have an CVM mechanism in two states, and with that we have not solved anything.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Mr President, corruption is on the agenda in too many Member States of the European Union and, of course, must be tackled. It has to be hit at its root. This means that the various ways and routes for transporting crime products to third countries must be closed. On this basis, a specific policy must be developed because things have been left to their own hands. The fact, of course, that at European Union level we have only four international mutual assistance agreements shows that we are far behind, only with Japan United States Norway and Liechtenstein. What about Switzerland, where the illegally acquired money is transferred? There must therefore be a clause so that no trade agreement of the European Union can be done if the anti-fraud assistance clause does not exist. In this way alone, we can practically reduce corruption and effectively hit those who progress with proceeds with proceeds of crime that they transport abroad.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: Mr President, it is a fact that for many years companies, both European and non-European, but also individual individuals, have been transferring assets and money to third countries. Most of this money is fraud. The whole transaction is carried out with the assistance of financial institutions, which often act in a fraudulent and opaque manner. Of course, the opposite is true. A lot of money from third countries is fraudulently coming to the European Union. When, in fact, this money transfer is combined with the activities of international terrorism, you realize that the risks to the European Union are much greater than the risks of simple fraud. In order to address this situation, States should not rely only on bilateral relations with third countries. The European Union must also intervene to tackle corruption, to conclude various agreements with third countries, through which money and assets, which are the products of fraud, can be frozen and returned to the country from which they moved to third countries.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I would like to thank Mr Ivan for his report. It is again timely. As we all know, it is our shared duty to protect the financial interests of the European Union. We need to ensure that misused funds and assets are recovered in the most efficient and most effective way, including, of course, from third countries.  I am convinced, like you, Mr Ivan, that the European Public Prosecutor’s Office (EPPO) which is currently being set up, will be a game changer in our fight against criminals and fraudsters. The EPPO will not only change the way Member States cooperate inside the EU, but will also have a major impact on the way the EU and Member States cooperate with partners in third countries. The Commission agrees that this is essential to strengthen the effectiveness of international cooperation in asset recovery and supports the development of CARIN, a network of operational law enforcement and judicial contact points on asset recovery, which covers more than 150 countries and jurisdictions. There is a strong complementarity between the Commission’s anti-corruption work and that of the Council of Europe Group of States Against Corruption (GRECO). The Commission continues the discussion with the EU Council on the choice of the appropriate legal framework for the EU accession to GRECO and we truly welcome very much the pragmatic approach of the GRECO plenary. Finally, EU level mutual legal assistance agreements can be good vehicles for judicial cooperation in criminal matters and they can also complement the existing agreements Member States have in place. At the same time, EU level mutual legal assistance agreements, as we all know, are lengthy to negotiate and to enter into force. They also require a high degree of trust in judicial systems. This means that standards in third countries, third states, as regards, for example, the rule of law, independence of the judiciary, fundamental rights, the fight against corruption, fair trial – the judiciary should first be compatible with EU standards before the EU engages in negotiations on such agreements. Eurojust also plays an important role here. It has just concluded various agreements with third countries such as Ukraine, Montenegro, and most recently Albania. This facilitates close and swift judicial cooperation in relation to third countries and ensures that the financial interests of the Union are protected and misused funds can be recovered in a proper way.

text: – Mr President, we have strengthened the Schengen Information System by making the exchange of information between Member States and the competent law enforcement authorities more effective. For example, when a non-EU citizen in the territory of a Member State of the Union commits an offence punishable by at least one year' imprisonment under the law of the State in whose territory he is located, that State shall enter into the Schengen Information System an alert which shall be transmitted forthwith in order to refuse that person's right of residence in the European Union, and also to re-enter the Union if it leaves the Union. Therefore, this alert system that the Schengen system issues is very useful in warning all Member States about a person who commits an offence and who has to leave the Union.

name: Daniel HANNAN
text: – Mr President, there are broadly three ways in which you can operate an immigration policy. You can have a points-based system where people arrive on merit and arrive with a commensurate sense of patriotism and pride, having, as it were, beaten off other applicants for their place. That was broadly the experience of the US, Canada, Australia and New Zealand historically. You can do what a lot of Europe did in the post-war era, which is to ship people en masse from overseas and put them to work for the government, that creates delays with integration, it creates regional and linguistic blocs. Or you can just allow people to sneak in and then give them citizenship if they manage to stay long enough. And that, by default, is the approach that most western countries are now taking. Now I just pose the question, what’s likely to be the attitude of a settler who has come by cheating the authorities and whose every interaction with the forces of the state in which he is settling have taught him to despise it? Isn’t there a way of ordering the need for legal immigration so that we disempower the people-smugglers and allow those who have done the right thing and applied properly to take priority?

text: – Mr President, the Schengen Information System can only ensure the security of the Union if Member States quickly, correctly and completely introduce information enabling the identification of persons who commit crimes or who violate Union rules and thus help the authorities to act immediately. Europol can provide prompt and quality information to Member States around the clock precisely to prevent acts of terrorism. The system may also protect persons at risk, such as unaccompanied children who cross the union borders and who may fall victim to trafficking in human beings and other forms of exploitation. name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: – Mr President, dear colleague, I welcome the adoption of this report and I’m glad that I could contribute also to the drafting of the LIBE Committee opinion on it. Looting on archaeological sites has happened at all times but has now reached an industrial scale. The economic and artistic value of the cultural heritage creates a strong demand on the international market, including the shadow economy. The illegal export is managed by terrorists or other criminal organisations, especially from the regions affected by armed conflict. I would like to remind you that the cultural heritage constitutes an element of personal identity together with language, religion, territory and the sense of belonging. We believe that the time has now come to go a step further: we must not only combat the illicit trafficking of cultural goods, but also ensure that cultural goods are fully used for European citizens. From this point of view, we have always striven for a policy of investment, of protecting cultural heritage, of preserving cultural heritage, which guarantees its full usability.

The European Parliament has contributed to the final form of this Regulation, e.g. by adapting individual categories according to UNESCO recommendations for the most valuable cultural goods, where a licence clause of origin is required for goods over 100 years of age. The aim of this Regulation is therefore to limit the financing of terrorism, in particular from areas where there is therefore a conflict of war. The European Parliament has also reduced some bureaucratic burdens, so this is not about restricting trade, but about restricting the illegal importation of cultural sites for the purpose of financing terrorism.
