If we want to talk about extremism, I would very much like us to see both sides of the coin, that is, the left-wing extremism. In addition, we also have extremism of a different kind that is emerging in Europe. There is a new anti-Semitism, and if you look at where it feeds and who it is fed from, you might want to look at the Labour Party in the UK, the traditional left-wing party, and its leader, Jeremy Corbyn. So it also needs to be condemned, and finally we have Islamic radicalism that leads to acts of terrorism, and these acts of terrorism have killed the most people in Europe in recent years. All the terrorist acts we have seen here have been committed by Islamic militants in recent years. So if we want to tackle extremism, please look at it in its entirety and not choose the parts from it. I therefore did not vote on this report.

name: Eleonora FORENZA
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I obviously voted in favour of this resolution, which I strongly wanted and proposed to the European Parliament. I welcome the adoption of the resolution itself, not without emotion. I think it is important that the voices that contributed to the drafting of this text are women's voices. I would like to thank the two colleagues with whom I wrote the first version of the joint motion for a resolution, three feminists who spoke against fascism, to testify to the fact that feminism is the strongest antidote to all forms of fascism, patriarchy and racism. I think that today the European Parliament can sing 'Nice hello'. It is a good morning for the European Parliament and I hope that it will be a wake-up call for Europe, a wake-up call for the Italian Government in which there are political forces that go to dinner with Casa Pound and others who consider anti-fascism to be something outdated. I dedicate the adoption of this resolution to all my comrades and companions who have been victims of fascist violence, in Bari and throughout Italy.

name: Urszula KRUPA
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by I supported the resolution on animal welfare, the use of antimicrobials and the environmental impact of industrial broiler farming, and I would support any regulation that would improve food safety. A huge problem in modern farms, and not only chickens, seem automated, huge, factory-like, several thousand farms, where it is difficult not only to maintain animal welfare conditions, including birds, but above all to provide healthy meat for farmed animals, including chickens.  European law allows a density limit of 33 kg per m2, sometimes even more, which means that there is an area smaller than an A4 sheet per chicken. Therefore, not only does it be necessary to ensure lower stocking density, but access to natural light, better air quality, preferably natural food without hormones, antibiotic growth factors, herbicides, pesticides, genetically modified feed, as well as a reduction in ammonia emissions, which together should reduce the need for antimicrobials. It would also be important to protect the environment with the minimisation of fetor and noise.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Mr President, firstly an observation. We spent eight minutes today arguing whether we should continue with the vote or not and then when we decided to continue with it, it took us, I think, 12 minutes. So I think it’s not your fault but it is something I think the Presidency needs to look at, so it doesn’t happen again. A Uachtaráin, maidir leis an ábhar seo, tá áthas an domhain orm glacadh leis na moltaí anseo agus caithfimid ár ndícheall a dhéanamh chun troid i gcoinne athrú aeráide agus beidh mé ag dul go Katowice sa Pholainn ar son na Parlaiminte, mar a rinne mé i bPáras agus in Marrakech do COP21 agus COP22, an t-aon Fheisire ó mo thír féin a bhí ann agus pribhléid mhór ab ea é. Ach anois, caithfimid gach iarracht a dhéanamh chun ár bpláinéad a ghlanadh suas agus tá dualgais ar chuile thír, mo thír féin san áireamh, chun ár ngeallúintí a chomhlíonadh agus má dhéanann gach duine é sin, tabharfaimid pláinéad níos fearr don ghlúin atá romhainn.

name: Dobromir SOŚNIERZ
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by I have not yet been able to speak in such an empty room. There are four of us here, as I count well, outside the presidency, but every record is unbeatable, and we are also looking boldly to the future.  With regard to the Katowice Summit, I hope that issues such as the nonsensical Erasmus programme, which encourages people to drive pointlessly across Europe instead of studying on the spot, will be addressed there, at the expense of others, emitting various carbon dioxide and other greenhouse gases along the way; such as the paperology that this Parliament also generates, like all those tonnes of paper that it prints with its resolutions, as nonsensical as that of neo-fascist violence. Maybe the subject of two houses of Parliament, which emits carbon dioxide, carrying documents from one place to another, drivers, assistants, etc. Perhaps the subject of a parliamentary hotel that could be built at Parliament's headquarters, rather than carrying MePs over and over again, emitting carbon dioxide around Brussels and increasing traffic jams there; maybe the topic of nuclear energy, which is not known why many people are opposed here, and which is clean energy. I hope that such topics will not be forgotten here.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Mr President, having previously led negotiations on the General Data Protection Regulation for Parliament’s ITRE Committee, I know how important it is that citizens’ data is respected and used appropriately. The misuse of personal data is without question not to be tolerated and the recent Cambridge Analytica scandal completely undermined the privacy of European citizens. Not only was this data breach an abuse of such personal data, but the use of improperly obtained data to build voter profiles with a view to influencing elections was a complete manipulation of the electorate. In 2016, a special Eurobarometer on online platforms reported that over half of EU citizens are concerned about their personal data on the Internet and no doubt this figure is now much higher. It is essential that Facebook takes the necessary measures to prevent further breaches of data and makes changes to its platform to comply with EU data protection law and provide sufficient protection to European citizens' data.

name: Jeroen LENAERS
text: Thank you, Mr President. Mutual recognition of diplomas is crucial to our cross-border labour market. We have already taken the necessary steps in recent years, including with the European qualification framework. It is good that this is being highlighted positively here today. But more steps are needed. These steps do not necessarily have to be taken at European level. For example, I am very pleased with a project that the province of Limburg has started together with Germany and the Benelux to remove as many barriers as possible in regional level in relation to the recognition of qualifications. Because it is especially important that in a border province like my own beautiful Limburg that job seekers can also take advantage of opportunities on the other side of the border. First of all, it requires recognition of their diploma. It is important that we take these kinds of regional initiatives, which ensure that people can really benefit from the good effects of cross-border opportunities in practice, that we therefore support these kinds of initiatives from this Parliament wholeheartedly and very warmly.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the Commission's statement on the "Fair market for industry" (2018/2683(RSP)).

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, thank you and thank you very much for having this debate. It’s a very important debate to have about the environment for our industry, to grow, to create jobs, but also to innovate, and I think the important thing in this debate is that Europe has a good and strong starting point.  If you want to take a look at the statistics. Europe has a very large deficit when it comes to raw materials, in particular energy. But the thing is that we have a very large trade surplus in manufactured goods, like cars, machines, chemicals. In other words, Europe’s part is in a value chain where the jobs are and where the value is created, and this is how we have brought it so far. And if you don’t want to look at the statistics, look at the magnificent European companies as you see them and as you see their products every day.  So, we have a solid industrial base thanks to European innovation, thanks to European productivity and thanks to our internal market which rests on fair competition and openness.  But we can do more. We can do more to level the global playing field and to create opportunities for a fair and open internal market. There’s plenty of work ahead of us to remain competitive and to shape globalisation so that it serves our citizens and builds on a level playing field, in particular when it concerns subsidies, reciprocity in public procurement and screening of foreign direct investment.  A rule-based system which is fair, where open markets is the rule, that’s our interest. But it’s being challenged by some of our partners questioning the global rule-based system and cooperation. The Commission is working to enforce the existing rules, so that when we trade with Japan and with the US, well, we don’t only trade, we also discuss how to strengthen the World Trade Organisation’s rules on industrial subsidies.  In relation to my portfolio as Commissioner for Competition, we also have started a dialogue with China about subsidies and fair competition.  As to procurement, we already have rules in place which allow a buyer to reject an offer which is unrealistically cheap, but also here we can do more. Foreign bidders take part in public tenders all across Europe, yet European bidders, they often find ‘buy local restrictions’ when they bid in foreign countries with European goods, and this is why the Commission has proposed an international procurement instrument. Once adopted, it will ensure reciprocity and not only that, it will also strengthen our leverage in trade negotiations with third countries to open their markets for fair procurement processes.  And we also have proposed a framework to screen foreign direct investment that affects our security and public order. We continue to work with the Parliament and the Council to make progress on these proposals. But we also need to make good use of the tools that we have already. For instance, to apply modern trade defence mechanisms to maintain fair competition worldwide.  And when we think about the challenges ahead of us, in particular those that relate to digitalisation, it’s important that we factor in how competition helps us to make our industries competitive. Companies have to compete and when they do, well, they are encouraged to make the products that consumers want, to develop new business ideas and attract even more businesses. And that’s good for consumers and for companies.  When a company is a consumer champion in Europe, well it can conquer consumers in all corners of the world, provided of course that it has open and fair market access.  All companies, big as well as small, should have a fair chance to achieve this also when they are faced with large multinationals, and that is why we stop dominant companies from shutting down competition from new competitors, and this is also why we have to review mergers, at least the large ones. Well, we approve almost all mergers that are notified to us. Over the last 10 years more than 3 000 mergers were looked at but only seven were prohibited, were blocked, and in only slightly more than 5% of cases companies proposed solutions to our concerns, for example to sell a factory to a competitor to preserve competition in Europe. Many of the mergers that we have approved, well they have strengthened European companies like Peugeot and Opel, like InBev and SABMiller, like Siemens and Gamesa, world-wide known competitors.  But we should not confuse the size of the individual company with the strength of our economy. These are not necessarily the same thing. For every company that wants a merger to happen there are often many European companies that are affected customers. Steel is a good example of that. It makes the steel that goes into our dishwashers, cars, machinery, and these are businesses that boost our exports. Steel users, well they employ over 30 million people in Europe. So in our merger cases, we ensure that steel companies continue to compete, so that prices stay competitive for all the many, many businesses that need steel in their production.  And just to finalise, a few words on the state aid rules, because companies cannot get state aid simply to shut down a factory and move it to another European country. It is prohibited in a fair single market that taxpayers pay for jobs moving from one country to another. But we do approve state aid that creates jobs in Europe, if they do that without distorting competition. Just last month we authorised Slovakia to support Jaguar and bring new jobs to the disadvantaged Nitra region, jobs that may otherwise have been created outside of Europe.  The Commission also simplified the rule book for state aid that doesn’t harm competition. So, now that 97% of state aid measures go ahead without needing Commission approval, Member States decide for themselves on the basis of a common rule book.  We proposed an investEU fund to support EUR 650 billion of investment. A new research and innovation programme, Horizon Europe, with EUR 100 billion to invest. Both programmes would let national funds be combined with European funds, and we want to make that as easy as possible, because industry is at the heart of our European economy and we want an industry that’s competitive and creates jobs and wealth in Europe. But first of all, we want it to serve our citizens and that’s why we defend open and fair markets in Europe as well as in the rest of the world.

name: Seán KELLY
text: thar ceann an Ghrúpa PPE. – A Uachtaráin, a Choimisinéir, comhghairdeas as d’óráid. Aontaím leis an méid a dúirt tú agus cuireann sé bród orm labhairt ar son mo ghrúpa, PPE, ar an ábhar tábhachtach seo. Go háirithe, ós rud é go bhfuilim i mo chomhalta den Choiste um Thionsclaíocht, um Thaighde agus um Fhuinneamh chomh maith. Mar a dúirt an Coimisinéir, is iad na tionscail a chruthaíonn jabanna agus saibhreas san Aontas. Therefore, it is vital that the EU prioritises the needs of the industrial sector and provides sufficient support for its growth in the coming years. I was recently appointed as EPP-ITRE rapporteur on the new investEU programme which the Commissioner referred to, which will use a budgetary guaranteed to mobilise investment into sustainable infrastructure, research and innovation, SMEs and social investment and skills. This 650 billion fund provides an excellent opportunity to promote competition in the industry sector across all the Member States. As one of the flagship programmes of the new EU budget, it will constitute a significant part of our long-term strategy for industry in Europe. With a view to building a strong, sustainable industry sector, SMEs and start-ups should be prioritised. I believe it would also be important to have advisory hubs in each Member State to inform stakeholders on access to EU funding. We must facilitate the industry sectors’ growth, not only with funds, but also with information and above all, ease of access to those funds, which has not been the case sometimes in the past. In this way, we can accelerate digitalisation and innovation, encourage an entrepreneurial culture and increase competition in the industry sector. Earlier this year my colleague Heinz Lehmann's Committee of the Regions draft opinion on a European strategy for industry pointed to the importance of cities and regions in supporting innovation in industry and in promoting industrial adaptation to the digital advances. Local and regional authorities have a lot of influence in areas such as infrastructure, export support, research and innovation, education and skills, SMEs and regulation, all of which are crucial for a globally competitive industry. Technologies are developing at an ever-increasing pace. We should see this as an opportunity, particularly in prioritising industrial growth which is environmentally friendly. Energy is key in determining the competitiveness of the European economy and in particular of industry. A sustainable supply of energy at a reasonable cost to households and businesses, in particular industrial consumers, is crucial. And finally, labour mobility across Europe is an important aspect of industry competitiveness. We need to promote the importance of digital and linguistic skills in order to support employability of workers abroad. We must also increase efforts to encourage participation of women in the labour market with a particular focus on female entrepreneurship, and I’m quite sure, Commissioner, you agree with that.

name: Edouard MARTIN
text: On behalf of the Group of S and D. - Mr President, thank you Commissioner for coming here to discuss a subject that is close to our hearts. You talked about markets, investments, products, competitiveness, etc., these are obviously important themes.  I would like to focus on workers and citizens, because a company, an industry, is not just a place where you produce a consumer good, it is much more than that. An industry is also what creates a link, it is what creates wealth, not just for shareholders, but for a territory, a pool of employment and that is thanks to this that we have nurseries, schools, hospitals, roads, etc. However, on the day these industries disappear, the whole society disappears and the bill is presented to society.  I will tell you about two cases: Alcoa in Spain and Vallourec in France. These are two multinationals that have benefited from subsidies with tens of billions of euros in public aid to establish themselves in areas of the world where the constraints are less. The question is what are you going to do, Commissioner, when those productions that will be made elsewhere will return to the European market. What are the constraints on these industries? Why am I saying that? Because indeed, if the view of the European Union - and I know it is not yours, but we have to go further than that - is that multilateralism creates wealth, who should we ask ourselves for? Multilateralism is above all laissez-faire: tax laissez-faire, financial laissez-faire, economic laissez-faire, is above all the law of price. It's the lowest price that wins the market. However, we know very well that the lowest price is necessarily less so-called conditions: less social, economic and environmental. It's still absurd - to say the other, that it's Trump who denounces this. So it does so in a detestable way, of course, but in reality - and if it were not so serious, we would laugh about it - it is precisely the inventors of ultraliberalism who today point to the flaws of the WTO system and rules. We can't keep playing when we don't all have the same rules. When the European Commission was about to recognize China as a market economy, we were putting the industry at risk, and everyone said it! Four million industrial jobs could be lost in a few months. And yet it was a proposal from the European Commission! What was at stake? What were the political pressures? Where is the citizen? Where's the worker? So I just have this message to send us collectively, and I know you are sensitive to that: if you want European citizens to get a little closer to the European Union, we have to change the rules of the market and the WTO. I invite you to rebound on the proposal of the Canadian Prime Minister, Mr. Trudeau, which says "chiche, let's go, let's put the WTO rules back on the table because otherwise it is the law of the fittest" and you know very well that the Chinese, with hundreds of billions of dollars in subsidies, will kill us all economically; if the watchword is to be cheaper than cheaper, we Europeans will never be able to make the weight. It is our social model, it is our societal model that is at stake, it is more than competitiveness, innovation or winning markets, it is the European social model, the model of freedom, democracy that is at stake behind these industries. And I'm talking about it, because I come from a region that has been heavily industrialized and is now heavily deindustrialized. We make the nest of all populists, we make the nest of all nationalists, because when a factory disappears, you turn around, there is nothing left, it is the desert. And we Europeans have no answer. So I would like to see the maintenance of jobs and industries, an objective reason for the fair market, because the market will only be fair if it is social and if it is sustainable while respecting the planet and the environment.

name: Urszula KRUPA
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Commissioner, i would like to thank you very much for In my opinion, it is reasonable to ask whether there can be a fair market for industry at all in a situation of liberalisation and globalisation, characterised by many negative phenomena with global terrorism, the rise of social inequalities as a result of the uneven distribution of goods and services, the catastrophic extent of the environmental threat, the spread of demoralisation, the incapacitation of peoples, the destruction of religion, tradition, the dominance of consumer society over creative ones.  While the European Union has strict rules in place to prevent companies from abusing their market dominance, in practice, especially in central and eastern European countries, the internal market is dominated by huge corporations, in addition to trading cheap goods from Asia, eliminating small and medium-sized enterprises.  That is why, in my opinion, additional questions are well-known. How does the European Commission initiate and activate small and medium-sized enterprises with job protection in the Member States, especially in the event of a downturn or economic downturn? What are the Commission's fiscal tools? What are the customs barriers to prevent cheap products from outside the Union from flooding the market, leading to a recession of parts of industries? Has an action plan been developed for the development of industry in the medium- and long-term perspective, especially strategic industries such as the fuel and energy industry, so that european industry's share of the EU budget is above 20%? How does the Commission interfere in bilateral agreements relating to the industrial sector, in particular fuel and energy, between Member States and a third country outside the Union, affecting distorted competition in the economic sector? An example is Nord Stream.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: on behalf of the ALDE Club. – Dear Chairman, Dear Madam Commissioner, I want to support your presentation immediately at the outset, as it is reasonable, logical and aimed at preserving our industrial competitiveness. I also want to share some thoughts with you. Namely, I am convinced that the world as it was, or as we knew it 10, 15 or 20 years ago, is definitely changing. We have a situation where today in North America someone is shouting America First. We have a situation where in the east China is grabbing harder and stronger and there is no doubt that the world has changed, and that we in the European Union are still, in a way, playing by some old rules or we want, in a way, to create a world where there will be more justice, honesty, equality, competitiveness and democracy.  However, we see from both left and right, both from the west and from the east of Europe, that things are changing and that this is not so. This is where I want to express my concern and share with you the thinking where, as the European Commission and the European Parliament, we should also make our alternative to what we have consistently advocated so far. And that's why I'm saying, and I've told you here once before, if this one says America First, let's start thinking about whether maybe we need Europe first, because we have to guard our jobs, we're accountable to our citizens and fellow citizens, and if we keep doing this, I come from liberals, like you, but if we continue to overly liberal policies where there will be no help for industries , where there won't be too much social sensitivity, I don't think it's going to be good. Then truly populists in Europe will find room to attack our benevolent policies. That's why I think it's very important that we talk openly about it and see how much globalization can help at the moment, but it can also help. I can't and I can't, of course, mention what's on my heart and what you know is on my heart, which is the shipbuilding industry, which has practically disappeared in many countries of the European Union. There is a chance that this will happen perhaps, unfortunately, in my country, in Croatia. Because of my own weaknesses in the shipbuilding industry in Croatia, but I want to point out one fact that happened in the European Parliament. We had a conference together with Sea Europe and many other shipyards in Europe from different countries and everyone is worried. But, Madam Commissioner, everyone is concerned with the conclusion that in ten years we will lose the shipbuilding industry in Europe if we don't make a difference. You know the leadership program, you know the various programs, and I ask you to take this situation extremely seriously because without the shipbuilding industry we know that we are losing many, many indirect jobs.

name: Klaus BUCHNER
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Mr President, I would like to thank the I would just like to comment today on a very specific point on competition law. It is good that there are rules in Europe that seek to maintain competition and therefore prohibit the merger of market leaders. But it would also be important to limit the size of companies in principle – which unfortunately is not the case – and to limit their influence and dominance in politics and the economy. But we must bear in mind – and this has already been said a few times now – that Europe is not alone. In other words, we must take account of the situation in the world. This is done on an ongoing and o'going board by our free trade agreements, by our customs agreements. That is why it is an anachronism to say that we only look at the European area when it comes to competition from companies. Let us remember that there are a whole range of products where there are only one or two or a maximum of three companies anywhere in the world that are worth it at all. Take high-speed trains as an example, we take processors from computers, or earlier also hard drives. In the end, there was a single company in the world that still built reasonable hard drives that could best be used here. Let us stick to the example with the trains. It is the case that Siemens has now been urged to take over Alstom. But even the merger of these two large companies, which are building high-speed trains, will not be enough to utilize production to make investment profitable for a new generation of such trains. You have to look at that all over the world. In other words, we simply have to go one step further here. In short, I would simply ask that competition rules look at the new situation created by – but not only – by the free trade agreements that have taken place throughout the world situation, specialisation in individual techniques. We have to do that; anything else would be absurd in my opinion.

name: Jean-Luc SCHAFFHAUSER
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Mr President, just a preliminary remark, I would not want it to be taken on my time. When I go to Brussels and I only stay six hours, I only have half of my allowances. I am the only citizen of Strasbourg, a member of this Parliament. I see that there are very few of my colleagues; the same principle as Brussels should also apply, that if someone stays less than six hours there, they receive only half of their allowances for the day. So I would like to - I apologize, I know I am irrelevant - but I would like there to be reciprocity. I will now intervene, I will make my intervention on three levels: the Eurozone, the non-euro area and the new market data. Within the euro area, we have to distinguish things: we have a single currency and a single market. What is the comparative advantage? We wanted a single market precisely to have a comparative advantage. The stronger becomes stronger and the weaker becomes weaker. Look at what is happening for a country like mine, France: it has a corporate tax rate twice as high as in Germany. It cannot devalue, otherwise - it is in the Eurozone - it has to make an internal devaluation. If it makes an internal devaluation to regain competitiveness, it risks the fate of Spain, which took eight years after its internal devaluation to regain the level of growth and GDP it had previously had. So you see, we are in an absolutely impossible reform game, which is very serious, within the euro area. I had proposed an investment agency to promote the industry in the south, but the reality now is that Germany is increasingly industrializing or maintaining its industry and all the other countries are reducing their industry. What does this lead to? With the debt and the financial crisis, which is going to be the end of the system, because we are nearing the end of the system, there will be a financial collapse.  So, you see, you have to understand this internal mechanism to the institutions of the European Union that leads to this financial collapse, because otherwise you go into two other logics: transfers from the euro area budget - but with these transfers, you are assisted - or, and that is what you are doing, you are developing debt. This is the first point. The second point is outside the eurozone. It is clear - and we populists were the first to denounce this problem - that reciprocity must be guaranteed. It is not possible for China to put rights ... (The President withdraws the floor from the speaker)

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: – Mr President, the European economy is currently under severe pressure. We are in the midst of an economic rivalry between America and China. The global situation is difficult to predict, and many industrial enterprises are rightly asking how Europe can protect them from such external factors. I recognise that globalisation has contributed to the interconnectedness of the world economy, opened up new opportunities and put many people out of poverty. On the other hand, it is essential that fair rules and principles of fair trade are also respected at global level, so the Commission should consider all options to protect our industries and jobs, especially in areas where dumped and unfairly subsidised imports are taking place. At the same time, our industry is exposed to our own internal rules, which bind it to global competition. European competition rules should therefore not be set up in such a way as to put our businesses at a global disadvantage. For these reasons, the Commission should urgently develop an effective industrial strategy in order to reduce the vulnerability of our businesses.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: – Mr President, at the moment we are doing this debate, in my country — Spain — Alcoa has just announced the closure of two factories in the aluminium sector. This has to lead us to reflect on the role that European industry has to play and the need for the Commission to present this industrial plan which aims to strengthen our businesses; aiming to establish fair criteria for equal competition; that industrial plan that has to do with how it takes action against dumping that is taking place and that is unfair competition that is leading us to a failure like Europe. Therefore, we cannot stand by, especially in sectors such as steelmaking and aluminum, which are suffering from this sledgehammer, which are weakening and are closing and where we are losing jobs. It is necessary to act without contemplation and not to stand by.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, thank you very much for your remarks. I find this is very inspiring because we obviously share the same starting point: that fair competition, a level playing field – this is what we want. We don’t want harmful subsidies to be sort of smuggled in via trade. We don’t want prices to be dumped on us – that’s unfair for European industries. One thing I think is important in having this discussion, and it is that Europe is the largest economy in the world. Europe is an amazing place to do business. Although growth is slow, it is still the highest GDP per capita, with 500 million Europeans. It’s the world’s largest trading bloc, the largest trader in the world of manufactured goods and services, and we rank first in both inbound and outbound international investments. We are the top trading partner for 80 countries. Just to compare, that figure is only 20 when it comes to the US. Those facts shouldn’t lead to any kind of leaning back, or being self—absorbed, or think that everything is solved – on the contrary, because I completely agree that we are in times of change. But the important thing is to see what we have achieved in the European way, in strong societies with social benefits, with a tight fabric that allows people to have jobs where they can provide for their families. I think that it’s important that we take all this achievement and put that in our fight for change, for making the market, the industry and globalisation serve citizens. This is why the strategy is so manifold, because I completely agree with what is said by Ms Smolková and Mr Blanco López: that of course we need to work strategically at this. This is why it’s not just a matter of a fair level playing field within the European Union. This is a global effort to make this happen. I also completely agree with Mr Martin, who says: well, we have to figure out how to enable change so that people feel that they are the masters. Because if we just abandon areas that used to be the home for important industries and workplaces and leave it at that, of course, everyone gets frustrated, because you don’t see your sons and your daughters having a fair chance. And this is why, with the combined efforts of the Commission, the Parliament and the Council, things can be put into effect. But it is not just to change, it’s also to maintain and develop our industries. And this is why we do our best to enable Member States to work together on important projects of European interest. Take microelectronics, take the Battery Alliance being built as we speak, because this shows the strength of coming together in Europe when we do things together. Ms Krupa rightly mentioned all our small and medium—sized businesses. Because when we talk about industry, it’s important not just to think about the giants, but also to think about the many smaller businesses – who are either the customers of giants or the suppliers to giants – to enable the network of European industry to work well. This is why it has been so important in the Juncker investment plan to provide capital for small and medium—sized businesses, because this is one of the most under—debated issues, that you need capital in order to grow. You need access to financing, otherwise, how could you create the jobs. I think that’s a very important point in our discussion that we don’t focus on just the big ones or just the small ones, but see the network that they create and that they have the need for one another. So thank you very much also for mentioning that. Mr Jakovčić also rightly points to these chains that we’re in. Obviously it’s very important that Europe master the different crafts and that is why it is important when, for instance, shipbuilders come together to figure out how to make sure that we have a competitive shipbuilding industry in Europe to deliver state of the art. There are a number of specific discussions but there are also a number of discussions that are European—wide. Mr Buchner talks also about trade and I’m very happy to support the work of my colleague, Cecilia Malmström, because what she has done over the last couple of years is basically to retire the old concept of free trade and replace that with a concept of trade agreement, where you actually have tools to say, well, I will not import despicable working conditions or animal welfare that we will not accept here. We want trade also in that to be on an eye-to-eye basis and that is the modern way to proceed. Not just to say trade is just about lowering tariffs. No, trade is also about actually having reciprocity in the way things are done. That is important for us, as the Commission, to enable this environment for European industry to thrive; not just the big ones – and we have big impressive industry in Europe – but also all the smaller ones who are part and parcel of the creation of this Europe that we live in, in which – at this point where we speak – more people than ever have a job. And with all that achievement – and with your engagement and our agreement on a level playing field and fair competition – I am certain that we have what it takes to meet this challenge and to make this change happen for the benefit of citizens and not counter it, because in that I think Mr Martin has the exact point; that this is now where change should be inclusive and not over people’s head, so thank you very much for this.
